awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Solar Desalination of Oilfield Produced Water with Nanostructured Gel Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology for the desalination of produced water from the energy industry. The energy industry is currently facing increasing environmental and economic pressure with regard to the production of wastewater from its wells. This produced water has a very high total dissolved solids (TDS) concentration, reaching salinities up to ten times that of typical sea water. The U.S. oil and gas industry produces a billion barrels of water annually. The vast majority (more than 90%) of this water is re-injected in geological formations for disposal or enhanced oil recovery. While re-injection is the cheapest disposal method at this time, there are concerns about forming pressure spikes in the drilled neighboring wells and induced seismic activity. In several parts of the U.S. (e.g., California, Texas and New Mexico), oil and gas production regions are located near water-stressed regions. The desalination and use of produced water as a potential source of potable water may provide additional water to these regions.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology to modify solar evaporation ponds, an existing method for the disposal of produced water for some oil and gas producers. The proposed technology uses two major modifications to these solar still/evaporation ponds: 1) placing hierarchical nanostructured hydrogel materials on top of the feed water to increase the rate of evaporation, and 2) adding a superhydrophobic coating to the glass at the top of the solar still to enhance the rate of droplet departure on the glass surface and move condensed water out of the way from incoming radiation. The proposed approach will use fully passive desalination technology without any moving parts. The low capital and operating costs associated with this approach make it more reliable and economically feasible for small-scale plants at oil and gas well sites, which are often located far away from substantial infrastructure. In addition, the proposed design may ensure zero liquid discharge to eliminate the problem of treating the ultra-high saline water that is typically produced at the end of the desalination process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The oil and gas industry generates large volumes of “produced water” as a byproduct of extraction processes. This water has high levels of salinity and contaminants, making disposal or reuse difficult and costly. This project aimed to develop a novel solution for desalinating produced water using a solar-thermal desalination system enhanced with nanostructured hydrogel materials. The project’s innovations focus on making desalination more efficient, scalable, and affordable, with potential applications across various industries requiring purified water.

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit of this project is grounded in its development of a solar-thermal desalination system incorporating nanostructured hydrogel materials and low-cost surfactants. The project’s key technical achievements include:

  • Technology Refinement and Scalability: The introduction of low-cost surfactants significantly improved the scalability and affordability of the desalination process. This adjustment not only enhanced the evaporation rates but also directly addressed cost concerns raised by potential industry partners, positioning the technology as a commercially viable solution for treating produced water.
  • Adaptability Across Water Types: Testing confirmed the system’s adaptability to diverse water compositions, particularly water containing high levels of sodium chloride, a major component of produced water. This adaptability highlights the technology’s potential for use in various field conditions and for treating water with different salinities.
  • New Market Validation: Customer discovery processes revealed significant interest from chemical manufacturing companies, which have specific purified water needs. This interest validated the technology’s potential for applications beyond the oil and gas industry, suggesting a broader market reach and expanding commercialization opportunities.
    •

 

These achievements contribute valuable insights into scalable desalination technology and enhance the scientific understanding of surfactant-enhanced hydrogel systems. The project supports the broader scientific effort to develop low-cost, efficient desalination methods with industry-wide potential.

Broader Impacts:

The project’s broader impacts extend across environmental, economic, and societal dimensions, supporting sustainable water management:

  • Environmental Benefits: The solar-thermal desalination system offers an efficient, lower-cost alternative to conventional produced water disposal methods, reducing the need for environmentally sensitive practices like deep-well injection. Additionally, discussions with stakeholders suggested potential applications of treated water in agriculture, which could further enhance its environmental value if regulatory changes enable broader water reuse.

  • Economic Viability and Market Expansion: The integration of low-cost surfactants enhanced the system’s cost-effectiveness, meeting a primary industry concern and making the technology feasible for large-scale adoption. By validating additional market interest from chemical manufacturing companies, the project expanded the commercial potential of the desalination technology beyond oil and gas, indicating a strong market trajectory.

  • Strategic Collaborations: The project team successfully established collaborations with key industry players, including Shell, Schlumberger, Evonik, and governmental organizations such as the Department of Energy. These partnerships provided critical support, feedback, and resources, accelerating the development and potential commercialization of the technology.

  • Enhanced Customer Discovery: Through a rigorous customer discovery process involving in-person meetings, virtual discussions, and participation in industry events, the team gained deep insights into market needs and challenges. This process was instrumental in refining the technology’s value proposition and business model, ensuring alignment with industry requirements.

  • Broader Societal Contributions: Stakeholder discussions revealed the potential for this desalination technology to serve industries beyond oil and gas, and the prospect of regulatory changes may further expand its use for agricultural applications. This broader adaptability positions the technology as a sustainable water treatment option across various sectors, contributing to global efforts to address water scarcity.

In summary, this project developed a scalable and cost-effective solar desalination technology with demonstrated market potential and environmental benefits. By advancing an innovative solution for managing produced water, the project contributes to the broader field of sustainable water management while laying the groundwork for future applications across multiple industries.
